statement:
Let $\alpha$ be a real number. The sequence $(1+\frac{\alpha}{n})^n$ is
monotone increasing for all $n>
|\alpha|$.

Let $n>|\alpha|$. We want to prove the following inequality:
$$\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{n}\right)^n \leq
\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{n+1}\right)^{n+1}$$ Since both sides are positive,
this follows by taking the $(n+1)$-th root and using the
arithmetic-geometric-harmonic means inequality:
$$\sqrt[n+1]{\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{n}\right)^n} =
\underbrace{\sqrt[n+1]{1\cdot \left(1+\frac{\alpha}{n}\right)
\cdots \left(1+\frac{\alpha}{n}\right)} }_{\textrm{$n+1$ elements}
} \leq \frac{1+n\left(1+\frac{\alpha}{n}\right)}{n+1} =
1+\frac{\alpha}{n+1}$$
